After 75+ hours of marching tiny soldiers across massive battlefields, I can confidently say this game has taught me three things:

Flanking is life.

Artillery solves everything (including bad decisions).

My inner general is apparently part Napoleon, part coffee addict.

The battles are intense, strategic, and sometimes hilariously chaotic-like when my cavalry heroically charges… in the wrong direction. But every victory feels earned, and every crushing defeat is a lesson (usually “don’t march into cannons”).

The campaign system is addictive, the attention to historical detail is impressive, and the satisfaction of outmaneuvering an army twice your size? Chef’s kiss.

10/10 – Would once again send men uphill into musket fire because “it felt right at the time.”

I have over 1200 hours of the game and have nearly achieved every single medal. It's an understatement to say I love the game and think there is a lot of replayability. I enjoy building your army, upgrading the units inventory, and slowly building brigades that are elite. Each time I play a battle I can try different strategies and approaches. The AI is fun to fight against and I feel its sufficiently balanced. My only recommendation is to launch a live player vs. player on a given map like the U.G. Gettysburg had. I recommend the game as it is fun. My main complaint is that the AI will always out number you. It gets weird when the start of a mission mentions that the enemy is outnumbered. You then get into it and you are outnumbered, but the mission is structured like you have the larger force. The mission will have a lower time limit and the enemy will be in very defensible terrain that you have to assault. The AI isn't that great and so to make up for that they just have more forces than you do or can have. The other complaint I have is that what you do in one mission only carries over for you to the next. If you wipe the enemy out and slaughter them that has no bearing on the next mission for them, however you will take all of those casualties making it best to do the minimum needed to get victory and no more. Overall the game is fun but isn't quite what I want for the ultimate game for a campaign of the civil war. I give it 7 out of 10.

I can grade this game on two scales: As a Civil War game we have, and as the Civil War game you and I probably are looking for. Luckily(?) in both cases it's more or less the same: It's okay. I don't regret the purchase on sale, but it's not that be-all-end-all Holy Grail of Civil War games the weird guys who know way too much about individual units in the 3rd day of Gettysburg and volunteer at the museum dream about. 

As a Civil War game we have, it is not only finished, but it also attempts to have a presentation that is not under the impression that Paradox UI's circa 2004 are God's gift to man. That means I have clear buttons and will not be going through nested buttons and menus just to order a unit or equip them. I can easily read the situation and the battle isn't just an abstraction of chevrons and NATO blocks smashing into each other on a map like a porno for the History Channel. It's not flashy and it sounds kind of weak, but it tries.

As the Civil War game the aforementioned CSA re-enactors probably want, you'll probably have to keep waiting or look elsewhere. The logistics part of the war is as simple as a market of buy/sell gear and a magic radius of resupply around a Supply Wagon unit in-game. The terrain is very Total War levels of simple, flat modifiers to movement and defense without many opportunities to do much but create chokepoints. Unit formations and frontage are basically absent, bar flanking. Above all though, the inter-mission strategy layer is the biggest and most comically simple offender and even seems to be made to be cheesed by design. It kind of makes the whole thing fall apart. Enemy forces are scaled to yours and there's not a dynamic ability to choose your objectives, you just have phases of one main mission historical setpiece that advances the war and 1 or 2 side missions to get gear and money before the next "act". These can weaken or influence the main mission, but the scaler still applies. So if I was to say, send the entire Army of Virginia to attack Uncle Tom's Cabin which is strategically worthless, suddenly there's not just 3000 Union soldiers, it's 30000 awkwardly shuffling in on an already cluttered map. If I slaughter these 30000 Yankees in a victory so total that it makes Bull Run look like foreplay, there's still an endless supply of them grown in vats and waiting to suicidally charge at Vicksburg or Shiloh, and the war doesn't ever change based on how you're doing up until you're apparently at DC despite killing several Gettysburg worth of men  in a side mission. The AI probably makes Lincoln sack another general from beyond the grave. The only progression is that you'll get new gear, some stat bonuses, and historical(and sadly missable) figures. That part really is commendable because some of these guys only show on lists of lists and aren't even really Wikipedia worthy. They can also die in ways remarkably less dramatic than their lives would warrant, as my Nathan Forrest died when I forgot to update his orders and he waltzed into the enemy.

tl;dr it's okay get it on sale if you're starved for Civil War stuff, beggars can't be choosers

Very easy to play, very rewarding when mastered. Most wargames iike this require working through a steep learning curve, but this game is amazingly easy to play. Click and drag controls your units and with simple control you can command a giant army of 100+ regiment/brigade level units. As you play through the first few battles you will be given more and more units to coordinate and command as you work your way to epic, gigantic battles controlling 5 Corps of units.
Each battle is a representation of battles fought during the civil war, there will be all the historic battles to refight and some flavour battles like a supply raid for example. Between battles you will recruit new units and purchase weaponry to fit them out. Your best infantry brigades you will fit out with the best rifles you can afford, while the newly recruited units you may have to supply with muskets until new weapons are available or captured from the enemy. Leaders and units will both gain experience and get better as they fight, officers gaining ranks and units being able to add perks. Your units will be a mix of Cavalry (melee or ranged), sharpshooters, artillery and infantry brigades. You will raise them, name them, select an officer - or replace dead/wounded ones -and equip them between battles.
Superb real time (pausable) strategy game, historic and epic scaled battles. MUST PURCHASE for any fan of tactical combat.

As a 25 year veteran of Total War and War of Rights, I am enthralled to report UGCW is a MUST-HAVE for any E:TW or Napoleon fans:

1. Dozens of incredible Quality of Life improvements over TW. Units move/skirmish/fire/retreat/reform much more intuitively. PLUS Detach or Re-Attach skirmishers from large infantry units seamlessly! PLUS Combine weakened units mid-fight!!!

2. Mouth-watering resource management. Manpower and Money, two simple resources. Do I buy horses and carbines for 500 men, or do I buy rusty old smoothbores for 3000 men?

3. Very difficult. Teaches me how to remain steady under fire.

4. Rogue-lite experience. Defeat is still rewarding.

negative.review: I've wasted ridiculous amounts of time on the campaign only to find that the AI repeatedly does what it wants when it wants regardless of the time and effort I put in playing. For some reason, the AI has teleporters and nuclear weapons in 1862 that break units instantly regardless of combat, leadership, quality, weapons, morale or anything resembling reality. No wonder nobody likes the other games in this series. I've tried my patient best as a wargamer of over forty years to get past one scenario, but when I come up against AI like this, I feel that it's just another game that sucks you into repeat playing until you realise that you can't win, and then they've got your money.

AI cheats to such an extension that it makes the game-play unplayable. My soldiers get tired VERY easily while the opponents never seem to get tired. They start a march to the battle location and by the time they get there, they are tired.

This game had so much potential: cool upgrade system, fun battle system. And then, you realize it has a timing system, and it completely ruins it. 

You don't get to leveling up until the 3rd mission in, and the first two seem more like tutorials, so the time mechanic is not as prevalent and makes sense. 

then you get into the real game. suddenly you can buy weapons and units, and level up, and it's like ok this is awesome-
but its a lie. 

I restarted the 3rd mission 4 or 5 times, trying to get it right. mind you, there is nothing that says you have a time limit. so when it hits, you're just blindsided. There isn't even a timer, or notification to let you know when the round will end. and when it ends, you can't replay it. which makes no sense, seeing as how you can manually restart whenever you want... until the timer runs out. then you don't get restarts, its just over and you move on with the campaign. 

I was so mad. The game already starts you off as an underdog, your forces are much weaker and very outnumbered by the enemy, so getting to where you can win is hard already. I got to a point, where my forces were so weak, i couldn't assault the enemy without losing. but i had taken out their cannon, and I could hold them off while my own cannon softened them up. So, while i was patiently doing that, having a great time, my win impending: boom. Suddenly, the round ends and it says draw. I was like, what the absolute F**k. 

the next round fared similarly, there was no real sign of time, but i'd learned. so i moved quickly, however the enemy is so much stronger than you, you cant really move that quickly. Once again, when i was on the eve of a hard won victory, it ended. this time saying defeat, when i was clearly about to win. 

That was it for me. The devs ruined this game by adding a needless time element, which only makes the game frustrating and pointless. I uninstalled this not feeling like i'd had a satisfying gaming experience, but instead feeling depressed about the wasted time put into the game. I don't usually write reviews, but this upset me enough to do so.

The game is not bad for 2017. It’s pretty realistic most of the time and the battles are somewhat enjoyable. The campaign is a cool idea, but it doesn’t offer much besides battles, which dont  really feel interactive or feel different from another IMO. The level system is also interesting, but a bit dry.
The worst part, in my opinion, is the melee interaction – it’s just horrible. Combined with the artillery, it becomes a joke. Placing artillery close behind line infantry lets them not only shoot through them, but also gives them protection, so they can’t be charged.
Overall, I’d rate it 6/10. It’s not horrible if you get used to the weird controls, but I wouldn’t recommend it, since games like "Master of Command" offer similar experiences, hopefully in a better way.

A garbage Total War knockoff tbh. The game has no tutorial, no explanation of how any of the combat works, nothing. It just throws you in and hopes you figure it out, which is awful if you haven’t played a Total War style game before. I’ve played a decent amount of Total War over the years and can say, the controls in this game just aren’t good. I like the fact you can draw a path that your units will follow, but that’s about where it stops. This game has no way of drawing depth of units, which is essential for a game where line infantry tactics are being used. I don’t want a unit that’s more than 3 rows deep, because it effectively neuters the extra infantry sitting in the back. Napoleon and Shogun 2 are my favorites (especially FotS), and they allow you stack units up in that manner and then spread them out into a thin, two row unit with kneel firing to maximize the amount of shots going out. While in this game, the units at the back still fire, I just find it to be lacking depth that you can’t do that. Beyond that, units do whatever the fuck they feel like at all times pretty much. Oh, you have a key point that expands your view of the battlefield and you’ve sent your cavalry to capture to get an advantage at the outset of the battle? Man it sure would fucking suck if your cavalry just rode their horses in circles and then ran off in a random direction, crippling your reconnaissance. Artillery is borderline useless for you, but has pinpoint accuracy and devastating results for the enemy. You have to shift your battle line slightly in order to avoid a flanking maneuver? Guess what pal, FLANKED! REAR FLANKED! It’s fucking bullshit that you slightly adjust the position of your unit, and the enemy is still in front of your unit, but it counts it as a flank for some fucking reason. I picked this game up on sale and it sucked. I honestly should have been paid $15 to play it. If you want an overall worse experience than what Total War can offer you, buy this.

I recommend anyone who attempt the campaign start with CSA route first. For the union side, the game should be called "Ultimate Blunder: Civil War". The campaign mode is terrible by the design. 

The impact of each parameter(career points, troop stats, commander impact) is way more complicated than what the description could provide. For example, if a troop has 100 efficiency, what would the player expect it to do on the field? Will it be able to devastate enemies in one single volley? Likely not. Therefore, the lack of calculation and positive feedback indicate that the learning curve basically doesn't exist. As a result, the player could not out grow their enemies power curve and could not effectively test out what went wrong. The dev somehow expect you to pick the few possible combination as if the player is trying to open a lock. This made the campaign start up essentially a puzzle solving game.

Every combat, there isn't anything more than a bloody slug fest of your enemies constant rout and regroup. Your troops are engaged constantly on all sides by superior numbers of enemies and have no time to rest. Your enemies have 120 cannons and you have 12 6-pounder. Nobody sign up for this. If people say it is historically accurate that CSA has 40k troops in Shihou, then why would union only have 30k? Even all my recruits doesn't add up to 40k! What? you tell me to to max out politic and brings army organization to 4? and I thought choosing army related skills surely would help more than politics!

I was so mad. The game already starts you off as an underdog, your forces are much weaker and very outnumbered by the enemy, so getting to where you can win is hard already. I got to a point, where my forces were so weak, i couldn't assault the enemy without losing. but i had taken out their cannon, and I could hold them off while my own cannon softened them up. So, while i was patiently doing that, having a great time, my win impending: boom. Suddenly, the round ends and it says draw. I was like, what the absolute F**k. 

the next round fared similarly, there was no real sign of time, but i'd learned. so i moved quickly, however the enemy is so much stronger than you, you cant really move that quickly. Once again, when i was on the eve of a hard won victory, it ended. this time saying defeat, when i was clearly about to win. 

That was it for me. The devs ruined this game by adding a needless time element, which only makes the game frustrating and pointless. I uninstalled this not feeling like i'd had a satisfying gaming experience, but instead feeling depressed about the wasted time put into the game. I don't usually write reviews, but this upset me enough to do so.

A garbage Total War knockoff tbh. The game has no tutorial, no explanation of how any of the combat works, nothing. It just throws you in and hopes you figure it out, which is awful if you haven’t played a Total War style game before. I’ve played a decent amount of Total War over the years and can say, the controls in this game just aren’t good. I like the fact you can draw a path that your units will follow, but that’s about where it stops. This game has no way of drawing depth of units, which is essential for a game where line infantry tactics are being used. I don’t want a unit that’s more than 3 rows deep, because it effectively neuters the extra infantry sitting in the back. Napoleon and Shogun 2 are my favorites (especially FotS), and they allow you stack units up in that manner and then spread them out into a thin, two row unit with kneel firing to maximize the amount of shots going out. While in this game, the units at the back still fire, I just find it to be lacking depth that you can’t do that. Beyond that, units do whatever the fuck they feel like at all times pretty much. Oh, you have a key point that expands your view of the battlefield and you’ve sent your cavalry to capture to get an advantage at the outset of the battle? Man it sure would fucking suck if your cavalry just rode their horses in circles and then ran off in a random direction, crippling your reconnaissance. Artillery is borderline useless for you, but has pinpoint accuracy and devastating results for the enemy. You have to shift your battle line slightly in order to avoid a flanking maneuver? Guess what pal, FLANKED! REAR FLANKED! It’s fucking bullshit that you slightly adjust the position of your unit, and the enemy is still in front of your unit, but it counts it as a flank for some fucking reason. I picked this game up on sale and it sucked. I honestly should have been paid $15 to play it. If you want an overall worse experience than what Total War can offer you, buy this.

I recommend anyone who attempt the campaign start with CSA route first. For the union side, the game should be called "Ultimate Blunder: Civil War". The campaign mode is terrible by the design. 

The impact of each parameter(career points, troop stats, commander impact) is way more complicated than what the description could provide. For example, if a troop has 100 efficiency, what would the player expect it to do on the field? Will it be able to devastate enemies in one single volley? Likely not. Therefore, the lack of calculation and positive feedback indicate that the learning curve basically doesn't exist. As a result, the player could not out grow their enemies power curve and could not effectively test out what went wrong. The dev somehow expect you to pick the few possible combination as if the player is trying to open a lock. This made the campaign start up essentially a puzzle solving game.

Every combat, there isn't anything more than a bloody slug fest of your enemies constant rout and regroup. Your troops are engaged constantly on all sides by superior numbers of enemies and have no time to rest. Your enemies have 120 cannons and you have 12 6-pounder. Nobody sign up for this. If people say it is historically accurate that CSA has 40k troops in Shihou, then why would union only have 30k? Even all my recruits doesn't add up to 40k! What? you tell me to to max out politic and brings army organization to 4? and I thought choosing army related skills surely would help more than politics!

I heard that people have to use mod so that the hard cracker of the content is more digestable.

Napoleon and Shogun 2 are my favorites (especially FotS), and they allow you stack units up in that manner and then spread them out into a thin, two row unit with kneel firing to maximize the amount of shots going out. While in this game, the units at the back still fire, I just find it to be lacking depth that you can’t do that. Beyond that, units do whatever the fuck they feel like at all times pretty much. Oh, you have a key point that expands your view of the battlefield and you’ve sent your cavalry to capture to get an advantage at the outset of the battle? Man it sure would fucking suck if your cavalry just rode their horses in circles and then ran off in a random direction, crippling your reconnaissance. Artillery is borderline useless for you, but has pinpoint accuracy and devastating results for the enemy. You have to shift your battle line slightly in order to avoid a flanking maneuver? Guess what pal, FLANKED! REAR FLANKED! It’s fucking bullshit that you slightly adjust the position of your unit, and the enemy is still in front of your unit, but it counts it as a flank for some fucking reason. I picked this game up on sale and it sucked. I honestly should have been paid $15 to play it. If you want an overall worse experience than what Total War can offer you, buy this.

I recommend anyone who attempt the campaign start with CSA route first. For the union side, the game should be called "Ultimate Blunder: Civil War". The campaign mode is terrible by the design. 

The impact of each parameter(career points, troop stats, commander impact) is way more complicated than what the description could provide. For example, if a troop has 100 efficiency, what would the player expect it to do on the field? Will it be able to devastate enemies in one single volley? Likely not. Therefore, the lack of calculation and positive feedback indicate that the learning curve basically doesn't exist. As a result, the player could not out grow their enemies power curve and could not effectively test out what went wrong. The dev somehow expect you to pick the few possible combination as if the player is trying to open a lock. This made the campaign start up essentially a puzzle solving game.

Every combat, there isn't anything more than a bloody slug fest of your enemies constant rout and regroup. Your troops are engaged constantly on all sides by superior numbers of enemies and have no time to rest. Your enemies have 120 cannons and you have 12 6-pounder. Nobody sign up for this. If people say it is historically accurate that CSA has 40k troops in Shihou, then why would union only have 30k? Even all my recruits doesn't add up to 40k! What? you tell me to to max out politic and brings army organization to 4? and I thought choosing army related skills surely would help more than politics!

I heard that people have to use mod so that the hard cracker of the content is more digestable.

AI cheats to such an extension that it makes the game-play unplayable. My soldiers get tired VERY easily while the opponents never seem to get tired. They start a march to the battle location and by the time they get there, they are tired.

This game had so much potential: cool upgrade system, fun battle system. And then, you realize it has a timing system, and it completely ruins it. 

You don't get to leveling up until the 3rd mission in, and the first two seem more like tutorials, so the time mechanic is not as prevalent and makes sense. 

then you get into the real game. suddenly you can buy weapons and units, and level up, and it's like ok this is awesome-
but its a lie. 

I restarted the 3rd mission 4 or 5 times, trying to get it right. mind you, there is nothing that says you have a time limit. so when it hits, you're just blindsided. There isn't even a timer, or notification to let you know when the round will end. and when it ends, you can't replay it. which makes no sense, seeing as how you can manually restart whenever you want... until the timer runs out. then you don't get restarts, its just over and you move on with the campaign. 

I was so mad. The game already starts you off as an underdog, your forces are much weaker and very outnumbered by the enemy, so getting to where you can win is hard already. I got to a point, where my forces were so weak, i couldn't assault the enemy without losing. but i had taken out their cannon, and I could hold them off while my own cannon softened them up. So, while i was patiently doing that, having a great time, my win impending: boom. Suddenly, the round ends and it says draw. I was like, what the absolute F**k. 

the next round fared similarly, there was no real sign of time, but i'd learned. so i moved quickly, however the enemy is so much stronger than you, you cant really move that quickly. Once again, when i was on the eve of a hard won victory, it ended. this time saying defeat, when i was clearly about to win. 

That was it for me. The devs ruined this game by adding a needless time element, which only makes the game frustrating and pointless. I uninstalled this not feeling like i'd had a satisfying gaming experience, but instead feeling depressed about the wasted time put into the game. I don't usually write reviews, but this upset me enough to do so. 

Don't get this game. it will ruin your night.
